metadata.case_name: Petitioner (Broker in Diamonds) v. Union of India & Ors

facts.text: Petitioner carries on business as a broker in diamonds and precious stones in Calcutta and enjoys credit and reputation as a well-known and respectable broker.

On May 4, 1955, Rummaging Inspector (Intelligence), Customs House, Calcutta (Respondent No. 3), armed with a search warrant from Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta (Respondent No. 4), searched petitioner's residential room at No. 32, Sir Hariram Goenka Street, Calcutta.
Search of steel almirah where petitioner kept stock in trade yielded nothing; petitioner denied having diamonds.
475 pieces of diamonds and one synthetic stone discovered in an old jacket in a wall almirah containing washed clothes and other articles.

Petitioner's signed statement: Rs. 10,000 worth of diamonds received from M/s. Ratilal Amritlal, 89 Zaveri Bazar, Bombay; rest purchased locally in Calcutta; did not remember names/addresses of local sellers; no purchase documents.
Petitioner escorted to Customs House; Assistant Collector asked for evidence that goods were not smuggled but legally imported on payment of duty and valid licence; permitted to go till May 7, 1955.
Notice served on May 4, 1955, stating reasonable grounds to believe goods illegally imported; required documents by May 7, 1955, showing legal import or purchase evidence.

On May 7, 1955, petitioner's advocates (Messrs. S. K. Sawday & Co.) wrote alleging unwarranted presumption under s. 167(39); requested reasons for seizure and 10 days for certificates from Bombay/Calcutta trade.
Further letters from advocates on May 9, May 16 (enclosing certificates), requesting reasons.
Assistant Collector replied on May 23, 1955: seized on reasonable suspicion of illegal import.
Correspondence continued: June 20, 1955 (petitioner), June 25 reply detailing initial denial, discovery in jacket, justification for proceedings; warned of decision on record if no explanation.
Further letters from advocates July 1, 4, 20, 1955; personal hearing July 21, 1955; letter July 22 with statement from M/s. Ratilal Amritlal.

Collector of Customs order dated September 12, 1955 (dispatched November 5, 1955): petitioner failed to discharge onus under s.178-A; confiscated under ss.167(8) and 167(39); absolute under Imports/Exports Control Act ss.3(2),4. Reasons: contradictory statements, suspicious hiding, afterthoughts.
Petitioner did not appeal to Central Board of Revenue; filed Art.32 petition.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.178-A, Sea Customs Act, 1878 (inserted by Act XXI of 1955), is unconstitutional as offending Art.14 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.178-A offends Art.14 by placing heavy burden of proof on possessor to show goods not smuggled, inverting ordinary burden, arbitrary power without standards, discriminates against innocent possessors.

respondent_arguments.text: Seizure on reasonable belief of smuggling; petitioner failed to rebut presumption under s.178-A; proceedings followed due process with notices, hearings, appeal remedies.

court_reasoning.text: Outlined Sea Customs Act provisions: ss.19,20,86,87,89,167 (entries 8,39),169,170,172,178,178A,179,181,182,188,191; complete code with remedies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act provides safeguards like search warrants by Magistrate on Collector's application, reasons for seizure, adjudication, appeals.

court_reasoning.text: s.178-A enacted per Taxation Enquiry Commission recommendation to shift onus for smuggling offences involving specified goods like diamonds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies to gold, diamonds etc., seized in reasonable belief of smuggling.

court_reasoning.text: Art.14 permits reasonable classification: s.178-A classifies specified easily smuggled goods seized on reasonable belief; rational nexus to prevent smuggling.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object; presumption rebuttable.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Budhan Chaudhury test; not arbitrary, applies post-seizure with procedural safeguards.

holdings.text: s.178-A does not offend Art.14; constitutional.

precedents_cited.relevance: Test for Art.14: reasonable classification with nexus to object.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Framework for import, duties, offences, penalties, searches, seizures, presumptions, adjudication, appeals; s.178-A shifts burden for specified smuggled goods.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 equal protection challenged; Art.32 for writ; others faintly argued.

outcome.summary: The Court held s.178-A constitutional, not violative of Art.14; petitioner failed to rebut presumption; no interference with confiscation order under Art.32.

key_quotes.text: "Where any goods to which this section applies are seized under this Act in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods shall be on the person from whose possession the goods were seized."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is now well established that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test from Budhan Chaudhury for Art.14 validity.

key_quotes.text: "The differentia on the basis of which the goods have been classified and the presumption raised by the section obviously have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
